title: How to ask someone, very politely, to reply to my email - Quora

response.answer_text: It really depends  on the context. Is yours a personal or transactional email? In case of personal emails, how close are you with the recipient?  And so on.  I'm gonna go ahead and assume it's a transactional/business email.  Firstly, don't jump right to it. Ask how the person is doing, how his business is shaping up, mention the weather if you have to, but SOMETHING!  Second, remind him of your previous correspondence. In a single line, remind him of your previous email.  Third, do NOT use words like "I'm sorry", "I apologize", "bother" etc. Don't portray yourself as a nobody.  Fourth, ask for a reply. Something like, "Was wondering if you've had a chance to decide..." "Do let me know if ..."  Fifth, sign off with good wishes.  Be succinct. Don't hesitate to ask for a reply.

It is common email etiquette to reply to emails, so unless your email is transactional (like a confirmation) you should expect a reply. But often, you won’t get a reply, that is because people are busy and you are probably not their #1 priority. I think we should learn to accept this, and start using some tactics to improve our reply rates. I send and receive hundreds of emails per day and these are some of the things I do to ensure that my emails are replied to. Here are some things that work great for me: 1 - End your emails with a call to action If you want to make sure they’ve gotten the email, then just ask! Try to end your emails with a simple yes/no question or call to action, such as “does that work for you?” or “if you’re interested, reply with a thumbs up and I can send more info.” Try to make it as easy as possible for the recipient to respond to you. People are lazy, make it easy!  2 - Use email tracking If you use Gmail or G Suite, there are loads of plugins that help you track if your emails have been received. I use Pigeon for Gmail (full disclosure, I am the creator of the app) to track if my emails has been read.  3 - Follow up! This is probably the least utilized but most important. If someone is not following up with you, send them another email! Often times, (from the perspective of the recipient) your email is not all that important and it is not prioritized and forgotten. That doesn’t necessarily mean you have been rejected, so you should try again. Sending at least one follow up message will increase your reply rate, and sending more than one will increase it even more. I use Pigeon for Gmail to automatically send a follow up sequence from inside Gmail!  Hope that helps!

I send one follow-up email which basically restates the first one, just in case the original got buried or deleted. After that, I call them. If I have to leave a message, I only ask them to call me back. I do not explain why. The purpose of the phone call is to make contact, not to leave a reminder. (If they have a human secretary who asks what it’s regarding, then give a general context. “Project X” not “my email about Project X”.) Once we’re having a conversation, I ask them when they will be able to reply to my email. I phrase it this way because it presumes that they will reply. I don’t ask “if” they will reply, because they could say no. If they waffle, I ask if there’s anything I can do to make it easier for them or I’ll explain why their reply is necessary, or when I need it. This part depends on why they’re delaying. I try to give appropriate encouragement. That’s always worked for me. I’ve never actually had to go to the next step, which would be a third email summarizing your efforts for the record, and listing the consequences. “Regarding my emails of August 2nd and August 9th, and our phone call of August 14th, I still haven’t heard back from you about the specs for Project X. If I don’t get the specs from you by the deadline on August 21st, I will have to give the unfinished plans to our supervisor with an explanation of why the specs are missing.” Like I said, I never had to go that far. Hopefully you won’t, either. Good luck!

End your email with the following statements, just before the “Thanks and Regards” part. In any event, a reply to this will be very much appreciatedAn early reply will be greatly obligedMay I ask you to do us a great favor by replying to this email, whatever might be your decision.You might have already perceived that our company is on a deadline and therefore we trust you will write to us promptly about your decision.We would be immensely pleased if you gave it a careful consideration and responded within the timeline.I sincerely hope that you will give the subject your earnest consideration and respond positively.We await an early, and we trust, a favorable replyThanks and Regards, Mathew Brinjals

Dear / Hi John (Use "Dear" or "Hi" depending on how professional your relationship is) In regards to our recent correspondence as seen in the email trail below, please would you be so kind to let me have your feedback? Your assistance herein is greatly appreciated. OR Id like to close finalise this matter and your feedback will be of great assistance. Kind regards, Ipsum Consult Team Source

By asking a question! I like very much the idea of asking a question regarding what was discussed. Pretty much any question will do. If you just inform them, they might or might not read everything, lying to themselves that they will answer it later. But when you ask a question, "assuming" that he read your original e-mail, like:"By the way, did I forget to send you any documents in my last e-mail?" or"Do you think I raised the price too much or that the client is going to go for it?" The best part of it is that you can add the question either at the end of the original e-mail or as a follow-up. Always remember to adjust the tone to the person you are talking to, but asking questions, I've found, is the best way to ensure an answer without demanding it.

A nice prompt is “a reply at your earliest convenience would be much appreciated.” Alternatively, “I look forward to your reply.” If you need a response by a certain date or day, let them known, include a time to give more of a sense of urgency. “I would appreciate your reply by Wednesday 7th at 5pm please.”. A gentle reminder the day before could read “just a gentle reminder that I am awaiting your reply and need it by tomorrow at noon please.” Hope this is useful

With business, I always end with: Thank you for your time and consideration in regard to this matter.  Then I will end with: I look forward to hearing from you soon. -OR- I eagerly await your response! And then I always end it: Sincerely, Your Name (note: sometimes I will just use my first name, other my full name – depends upon your subject matter – I may also include a phone contact number just below my name – incase they would rather call.

It depends on the type of email you sent. If it was personal, just follow up with quick note stating that you’re waiting for them to get back to you. If it was a business or professional email, send a second email, and reference your first email. You might start out by saying that you’d emailed them on such-and-such a date, but since you haven’t gotten a response, you’re including a copy of your original email, in case it had been overlooked. Remember to thank them for their time, at the end of your second email! In either case, don’t get snippy. Emails often get sent to the spam folder, they can get lost way at the bottom of a long list of emails a person gets in a day, or the person may be waiting for information from some other source before they respond to you.

Tip: Be brief. Be polite by asking if they've looked it over rather than accuse or point out that you haven't received it yet. Add value by giving them context for the urgency if needed or urgency about the next steps. Finish with a call to action so they know what you want them to do and why it's important. Use “WOULD YOU DO ME A FAVOR.” This is often used and you must use it when you are asking for a special request or favor. Other phrases for asking something to someone nicely are “DO YOU MIND,” WOULD YOU MIND, COULD I, WOULD IT BE OK IF, WOULD IT BE POSSIBLE, WOULD YOU BE WILLING TO, etc. Go to my Profile and you can find all about Cellulite material there...

Greetings,  I am eagerly awaiting further updates on the issue which we are facing on #####.For your convenience I have already attached the corresponding email along this reminder.  Have a great Day! Thank you.

You can invite a response in several very polite ways. I welcome your thoughts…What do you think…? (Seeking wisdom/advice is a highly effective way to pay others a compliment.)Would you please take a moment to reply?I very much need/welcome/invite your response.Slightly less polite, however arguably also very effective: Do you agree?Have you learned anything about this that you would be willing to share (in reply, in a lunch visit, by co-authoring a position paper, etc.)?What would you recommend?

I am sorry I don't understand the question.a) Do you want the person to respond with a "polite" tone in the mail (or)b) Do you want to politely send a reminder? If it's a), you cannot really ask, but you can try and understand why they are being rudeIf it's b) just send a note (don't reply all , serves well) saying, "hey, I am still waiting on this reply, can you please respond so I can consider this closed/continue with my other steps of action"
Dear Sir, It would be grateful, if I get the feedback/reply/response at the earliest; So that I can take the next steps/actions accordingly. Thanks and regards, xxxxx mobile:-

After a few days with no response, go into your sent items and forward the sent email to the person again and say that you hadn’t gotten a response and you wanted to check in to see if the person had had a chance to think about what you had asked. Let the person know that you’ll follow up in person, or by telephone, by a certain date. And then do so. If nothing else, you’ve reminded the person, very nicely, that you sent an email and that you: (1) Are not afraid to follow up; (2) will keep following up; and (3) will make the person talk to you if they don’t email you back. Chances are that you’ll get a response soon.

Thanks for asking. I say "please" and "thank you." If there's a deadline, I state what it is and explain why it's important. Here's an example: Dear (Name of Colleague), Please let me know if you can join us on (date in the following month) for a meeting about (topic).  (Names of other people) will be there, and what we hope to accomplish is (specific goals).  It would be really helpful if you could let me know by (date this week), because (reason for deadline). Thank you very much! Best regards from Deborah

When you send a mail, courtsey demands they send you a reply. Some may get too busy, to reply. Many don't even check their mails, and to ignore your mail, is rudeness.  Try re-sending and say " I request for an early reply". All depends on the relationship you share with the person from whom you expect a reply.

Case 1 :If you can meet the recepient face-to-face, politely say," I'm expecting a reply over my e-mail to you. Please respond in your earliest free time." Case 2 :If you can't meet the recepient face-to-face, politely send, " I'm expecting a reply over my e-mail to you. Please respond in your earliest free time."  PS : " I'm expecting a reply over my e-answer to you. Please respond in your earliest free time." Thanks. Happy Quorying.

It is true that many do not even acknowledge the receipt of an important mail.   They take it for granted that we know the mail was delivered.  Mostly they are keeping us confused about it.   The best thing we can ask is "It is great if you can reply my mail.  Please."
Dear Hiren,              Please provide 03 site D C  cleaning Snaps today anyhow.
